Middle Ages. This lecture will offer a brief biographical sketch of Proclus. It will situate him in the history of ancient Greek thought by offering something of the context within which his life unfolded. It will outline the methods and the content of his thought, as set forth in a 54-volume philosophy, the Commentary on Plato’s “Timaeus,” in a number of writings that constitute a 4-volume exposition of Plato’s writings from the Persian Wars to the dialogues of the Laws, and in many other writings under the unified heading of the Platonic Tradition. It will offer a brief look into his strategy for reading Plato; that is, it will concentrate on the principles that gave Aristotle’s own method its shape. How to Address a Business Envelope
Double-check the name of the addressee first. Once you have the right name, you need to identify what you are sending. Is it a bill, payment or receipt for goods and services? Is it a letter or other document? Is your recipient a person or company? These details need to go on the bottom-left portion of the envelope:
Keep track of where you’ll put the name of the addressee and what you intend to carry in your message as you type it out. Pay attention to these details on sample envelopes and templates to get familiar with formatting.
Use the appropriate term. If the addressee represents a large company, put the name of the company acronym in parenthesis when you put the legal name. Take into consideration how your corporate customer may like to have their acronym written.

giving scientists more tools to forecast how much of the gas will be released over the next century and beyond.
New research being published in the American Meteorological Society journal Geophysical Research Letters indicates that although the ocean’s only partial sequestration of excess carbon dioxide won’t solve climate problems, the dissolved gas will lead to rising sea temperatures in the next 200 years equivalent to about 6 degrees Fahrenheit, as well as higher acidity, potentially problematic for ocean life.
The research builds on previous University of Delaware-led modeling work that shows the top 20 feet of the ocean have already stored about 40% of the additional carbon that has resulted from the burning of fossil fuels since pre-industrial times. Carbon dioxide is dissolved in seawater and released into the atmosphere when ocean acidity can no longer handle the gas.

The artist was in many ways the epitome of the brooding artist whose destiny included illness (albeit not mental) and premature death. After graduating from Leiden's School of Art in Holland, he had to earn his living as a teacher, an arduous job for an artisan who had to support the family. To broaden his horizons and expand his scope at a time when varieties and thicknesses of oil and brush were already established techniques, van Gogh became engaged to a specialist at the Scientific Institute in Brussels who could, as an independent doctoral thesis explains, produce only primitive drawings.

larger companies own their server farms, smaller companies outsource their server operations to hosting businesses that provide their server space. professionals in predictive analysis by allowing the rendering of an outlook based on the most likely and probable alternatives to a decision. This technique is a simple but effective way to display a range of possibilities.
Decision trees are visual representations of possible sequences that may occur given certain information. It can range on a spectrum from a simple solution that is most likely to a set of options that might occur. Generally, it is a visual presentation of the potential impact that a specific decision can have. When used as a part of predictive analysis, it allows a project manager to identify alternatives to developing strategic or organizational best-case scenarios. Mainly this serves a purpose in list building rather than strictly analytics research in finding the best possible solutions, which is largely since the markings on the chart can reflect the potentially negative or positive outcomes that they reveal. Building on earlier studies by Kinsey researchers, the new study examines how a mother’s physical intimacy with paternal grandmothers affects relationship stress in later life. After two years of repeated “wandering interviews” with 63 Indian female couples in Western Indian, anthropologist Kelly McQueen, Ph.D., found that these women with strong ties between their mothers and grandmothers predicted less relationship stress. In particular, women who grew up with less paternal involvement reported less relationship stress among five different dimensions – experiences of emotional intensity, expressed anger, expressed playfulness and aggression, expressed conflict and the willingness to argue for your partner’s interests. The findings suggest that well-integrated mothers and grandmothers forge a strong relationship-oriented “network of grandmothers” that helps anchor youth, cushion adulthood,

6 October, the eve of the General Election, the BBC announced today.
At the same time, it was announced the BBC will broadcast live from all seven candidates in the EU referendum debate on 2 February.
The BBC was hoping to persuade all the major party leaders to stand and face each other in a debate but faced opposition from sources close to David Cameron, who ruled himself out at a meeting last month.
Instead Nick Clegg, the Liberal Democrat Deputy Prime Minister, and Nigel Farage, the leader of the United Kingdom Independence Party (UKIP), will go head-to-head on 6 October.
The hour-long debate, entitled The National and Europe: Night of the Live Debates, will be broadcast from 7pm and will put questions on the biggest challenges facing the United Kingdom direct to Clegg and Farage, as put by a studio audience, including questions on Europe.

ized radiolabeled nanobodies’ available to cancer patients (radiolabeled, in this context, means tagged with radioisotopes).
Radiolabeled nanobodies, or RLNBs, are antibodies that bind to and destroy unwanted, targeted cells. The antibodies — synthetic fragments designed to spur an immune response to certain diseases — are then tagged with radioisotopes to identify where they are in a targeted organism’s body. The treatment delivers a specific dose of radioisotopes to a cancer lesion, inhibiting tumor recurrence in a variety of cancers.

an interstellar object passing close to — and perhaps even diving into — the solar system. Matson Museum YouTube
At the beginning of October 2017, the Astronomers discovered something bizarre passing through our solar system. It was dubbed interstellar object 'Oumuamua, Hawaiian for "scout" or "messenger" that had been unleashed from a distant, outer solar system body beyond Jupiter. 'Oumuamua is extremely narrow oblong, reflects little to no light, has a strange chemical profile, and is at least ten times longer than it is wide. It was clearly not from our solar system.

UC researchers have designed a device that generates power in three ways: From droplet collection: The device catches snowflakes that melt on the thin film of the device; from evaporative cold: Water evaporates faster when nearby boiling water is used, releasing cold air against the device; and thermal: The device also produces thermal energy, which if harnessed, while a large amount, would produce less than an effective generator.

Historic African-American Cemetery Uncovered as Reno Ross Jeneri Building Finally Torn Down
On February 6th, the Reno Ross Jamers and Gineri Building – also known as “The Pearl” was torn down, bulldozed, dusted, and leveled. Now a large ring-shaped area where the old building sat will be built anew. What now remained were the bricks, as well as some big, old redwood tree logs laying on the ground. Floating on water atop these massive logs was a history that, perhaps unknown to most, tied back to the oldest known African-American neighborhood in Reno.

Pneumococcal diseases cause approximately three million cases of infections including meningitis, pneumonia and septicaemia globally, killing around 600,000 children under five each year.
Antibiotics sensitivity has been rising worldwide and is a serious health concern. The WHO provided 12 specific antibiotic medicines for treating bacterial meningitis, despite a lack of trials testing the feasibility, thorough knowledge, and global experience with such drugs for meningitis.

Marketers are employed in the public sector as well as the private sector.
Most people think of marketing as a strictly private sector activity, but the reality is people with sales and marketing backgrounds are hired by government agencies or nonprofit organizations to oversee and coordinate their marketing and communications outreach efforts. In part, because the resources for marketing activities in the public sector are a bit more restrained and tightly managed, it’s necessary for such employees to have versatile backgrounds to accommodate reduced marketing and advertising expenditures, as well as needing to launch marketing initiatives in diverse cultural environments.
Overall, the annual salary range for public-agency marketers is on the lower end of the spectrum, coming in around $48,000 up to $81,000 a year with significant industry specialties and experience. Public-agency marketers earn more starting salaries than in the nonprofit sector starting in the $34,000 range increasing to about $115,000 a year for experienced marketers interested in working for government departments or agencies

An eagerly awaited report from the World Health Organization (WHO) states that processed meats such as bacon and sausages cause cancer, and red meat likely does so too.
The France-based International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), which is a part of the WHO, has approved categorization for processed meat, labelled as "carcinogenic to humans." The scientists attributed “sufficient evidence to establish carcinogenicity of the consumption of processed meat.”
One IARC panelist cited by CNN, Dr. Kurt Straif, emphasized that further research is necessary for a solid conclusion regarding red meat: "Decades of research have shown that eating processed meat regularly is bad for your health, particularly if you want to avoid developing cancer."
While the WHO didn't quite reach level-two or highest category of dangerousness based on the IARC group's report, the WHO did describe it as "probably carcinogenic to humans."
On the bright side, based on the IARC's report, fruits, vegetables and legumes are unlikely to worsen your risk for cancer

Two UAE orders for military helicopters and guided bombs capped a remarkable year for procurement in which the Emirates became the largest foreign purchaser of US defence equipment, a Pentagon agency said.
Emirates Defence Industries Company signed contracts in March for USD1.9 billion, the 61st largest single year total by any international buyer, the Defence Security Co-operation Agency annual report shows. It was the highest total ever recorded for a Middle Eastern country.
In two other orders in March, the Dubai-based company bought a USD1.6 billion kit after-sales support package for its fleet of 80 US-built AH-1 Cobra attack helicopters and an Air Force contract for USD215 million for Paveway II and GPS-guided bombs.

Tom Carper (D-Del.), the Diesel Emissions Reduction Act (DERA) of 2019 would reauthorize the program at the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) under which public and private fleets can get rebates of up to 25% of the cost to replace or retrofit diesel vehicles with more environmentally friendly equipment, (e.g., diesel oxidation catalysts and selective catalytic reduction system retrofits). These latter retrofitted vehicles comply with EPA’s Tier 4 optional Low-emission Vehicle program (Rule 49), and use biodiesel blends as well. State and Federal DERA grants are provided to fund these trucks. Such emit less Greenhouse Gases (GHGs), particulates (PM) and other pollutants.

Surviving are his mother-in-law, Muriel Kope; seven children, Robert Eugene II and wife, Bethany, Double Springs; Bobby Deane and wife, Tammi, Amarillo, Texas; Loren Harper and wife, Janisse and Shawn, Altoona; Ryan Dwayne and wife, Heather, Altoona; Travis Todd and wife, Dana, Haddam Township; and Heather Gates, Altoona; nine grandchildren, Gaten, Emilea, Jalynn, Farrah, Madison, Diaz, Whittney, Justin and Isabella; two nephews, Jeff and Jim and one niece, Wendy.
He was buried in Altoona.

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth; Ireland would have to be. Ireland has moved locations where our women die with it falling into less favourable districts. On the other side of the world in Liberia, traditional ceremonies greet new mothers who have just given birth - a number of these women succumb to post delivery bleeding. What is important to always consider is the context in which we talk about mortality rates; all women who deliver in Ireland, regardless of where it is, are entitled women’s health care. In other countries, that is not the case. Death due to lack of care is considered preventable in Ireland would still be considered normal in some off-the-grid places in the world. Most gardeners think of diascias as low-growing bedding plants suited to a summer container or the front of a sunny border.
However Diascia personata breaks the mould and produces stiff stems of lightly scented flowers borne on short sturdy stems. It is a profuse flowering diascia that reaches 6 - 12 inches tall by 15 – 20 inches wide. The growth speed is slow to moderate. the plants bloom until autumn and produce abundant seed. Plant them in a fertile moisture retentive soil bordering on light sandy soil. It particularly excels in a rock garden where its height can be beneficial and twining stems can add to the structural interest. It is also suitable for use in hanging baskets where it can trail over plant supports including obliques and rounded bloom rose. Provide strategic pruning in early spring to encourage re-blooming.

The Airline Vikings were playing for the state football championship in 1972 against Neville on a bad night for football in Monroe.
But after the team had gathered itself, head coach Jack Gray called his seniors together for a talk. Among his seniors that night were lineman Ervin Lawyer, running back Mike Mahoney (his mother called him Mike Moorehouse) and quarterback Paul LeJeune, the team's spiritual leader.
"We could lose this thing to Neville, miss state by needing a field goal, then find out Vikings never do better than second place (because Neville threat was always there before the state championship game)," Gray was telling the Sunday story. "That's four years gone. Three more to go find (the state championship). Probably never do."
Gray, a local legend and former coach at Cedar Grove High School, says he knew the right thing to say.
"Ervin (Lawyer) shouted: 'Let's beat this team. Beat it North Dakota style. Beat 'em like we did in 1970."

In the summer of 1993, I had one of those experiences that stay with me for the rest of my life.
I spent 10 weeks in Europe, beginning with a six-week law-school summer session at Oxford, the traditional city of the Inns of Court. My great, good fortune was to have the teaching nearly all be Americans and Canadians, but more importantly, they were also the greatest of Brits. I thought we students spent days and days in a large, beautiful room learning about black letter law, international institutions and theories, the Fourth Geneva Convention and others, as if we were members of the International Bar Association. It was the most constructive education I have ever had as an attorney.
I rounded out this experience with two weeks studying in Amsterdam and one in England before my American friends and I headed north, taking the train into London for two days and one last night to exchange e-mail with college friends and actually catch the temperature in Western Pennsylvania. Ukraine has started siphoning off Russian gas bound for European customers. This follows the cutoff of gas supplies to Ukraine on January 1, after the two countries’ gas companies failed to agree on a price for 2009. In retaliation, Ukraine did not pay its winter supply bill, worth an estimated EURO 650, as required under the terms of the contract.
The siphon has started operations only yesterday, siphoning less than 5 percent of the gas normally bound for European customers, the Ukrainians claimed. Its operation raises questions regarding the potential for export to Europe to replace internecine internal bickering. Some analysts have claimed that such exports could replace gas sales to Europe due to occur at the end of the year as contracts come to an end. Theoretically, this could result in the gas being diverted from customer to customer, replacing the relationship between Russia and Ukraine.’
European customers may have to turn to liquefied natural gas imports, Norwegian off-shore treasures or even the U.S. for gas supplies.

Many people think the secret to great cooking is mastery of technique.
It helps, but it's hardly crucial. The key to cooking that tempts and satisfies, that brings people to the table, then brings them back again the next week, the next year, is something far subtler yet. It's reciprocity, that underfoot magic that happens when a chef looks out at the party from the kitchen door and wonders what she can cook for them. What can she make that tempts, what can she prepare that satisfies, what can she produce that touches, what can she concoct that brings, what can she create that rejuvenates?

California is lifting its drought emergency for most of the state after a winter of record rain and snowfall that followed a five-year dry spell.

CHICAGO -- A three-year-old boy died after a fire swept through his South Side home Sunday, police said.
Firefighters arrived at the three-story building on the 6700 block of South Bennett Avenue in Englewood about 11:20 a.m., city officials said. Calls to 911 described small rooms filled with heavy smoke and no fire, officials said, so firefighters focused on trying to rescue those inside.
Usually firefighters make a push to get into a building and attack a fire at its origin, but the heavy smoke and hoards of residents forced them to focus instead on rescuing animals and people inside. Crews working outside did their best to pull residents and one cat out alive.

History is filled with stories of bold pioneers who changed the world with their visionary ideas. There exists also, in the annals of innovation, a rich tradition of mad scientists with crazy inventions. These two notions are brought to life in a novel way at the New Mexico Museum of Natural History on the Albuquerque Museum campus. Inspired by "Darwin's Barnacle", a public radio show based on the real life work of scientists imaging pre-barnacle branching (formerly considered pre-barnacle tentacles), Museum artist Heidi Staples began exploring concepts to bring a 3D art installation to life that incorporated the history of the museum, the Museum's buildings, the underlying sciences and current research and activities at the Museum of Natural History. Adding to these were references to the human brain, including patterns observed while neurologists scanned the brain of the actor Jim Carey after his experience with brain resetting.

What can poetry do when faced with the daily realities of war and hatred, violence and terror, the crimes that humans enact upon each other and on the Earth? A cynic would answer nothing, would condemn the personal dimension of this art as pathetic, sentimental luxury. What the acclaimed poet Nazim Hikmet (1906–74) does with his poetry is confront reality with such force and depth as to unseat the reader from an easy cynicism. Hikmet worked in many forms: prose poems, elegies and sonnets. He was from the radical “Kitab-ı Ataû’l-Saçlâk” group (“Book of the Seasons” collection), whose poets were experimenting freely with form: one poem in their books is a single line, for example. RICHMOND, Va. -- Larry Scott was killed in Richmond’s Midlothian Village apartment complex Tuesday night.
A year earlier, Scott had been charged with conspiracy in a killing in that same apartment complex.
Scott was in a trailer with his girlfriend when he was called on the pre-paid cell phone. As he started walking toward the cell phone tower outside the apartment complex, he was ambushed and shot multiple times.
That man in the trailer: 37 year old Wilhemena Evans. Evans also was shot in the ambush and died after Scott died.
Police are searching for Alden Carroll and contract killer Timothy Brahms, the men police believe shot Scott and Evans and drove away in a GMC Savana. Carroll may have fled to the Washington D.C. area.

The August survey shows how key markets adjust their expectations in light of the recent sharp rise in bunker prices.
The index dropped by 4 points to 66 - in part due to a 3 point rise in bunker costs - and reflects a downturn across five of the shipping routes that impinge North Europe.

Proclus of Athens (*412–485 C.E.) was the most authoritative philosopher of late antiquity and played a crucial role in the transmission of Platonic philosophy from antiquity to the Middle Ages. This lecture will offer a brief biographical sketch of Proclus. It will situate him in the history of ancient Greek thought by offering something of the context within which his life unfolded. It will outline the methods and the content of his thought, as set forth in a 54-volume philosophy, the Commentary on Plato’s “Timaeus,” in a number of writings that constitute a 4-volume exposition of Plato’s writings from the Persian Wars to the dialogues of the Laws, and in many other writings under the unified heading of the Platonic Tradition. It will offer a brief look into his strategy for reading Plato; that is, it will concentrate on the principles that gave Aristotle’s own method its shape. (CN) – A federal appeals court in New Orleans upheld Mississippi’s three-drug method of lethal injection on the ground that the inmates challenging it had filed their complaint too late.
Mississippi’s unique injection process amounts to an illegal “meaningless sham,” according to Richard Dieter, head of the Death Penalty Information Center.
Mississippi currently only allows about half of the prisoners condemned to death in the state each year to be executed, because there are no qualified medical professionals to bring about execution and no methods to identify those qualified nurses. So any inmate challenging couldn’t seek preliminary relief, because the notice would have to go to the officials who could find the doctor – putting the inmate out of the time limit.
Deiter objected. “Because the last three doses are trivial, the apparent intent is disingenuous,” Deiter said.
A lawyer for Mississippi could not be reached for comment.

Addressing a business envelope correctly helps ensure that your letter gets to its intended recipient quickly. It’s important to follow standard practices for addressing correspondence, particularly if you are sending a letter to a large company with many departments, or a company located in a different city and state.
How to Address a Business Envelope
Double-check the name of the addressee first. Once you have the right name, you need to identify what you are sending. Is it a bill, payment or receipt for goods and services? Is it a letter or other document? Is your recipient a person or company? These details need to go on the bottom-left portion of the envelope:
Keep track of where you’ll put the name of the addressee and what you intend to carry in your message as you type it out. Pay attention to these details on sample envelopes and templates to get familiar with formatting.
Use the appropriate term. If the addressee represents a large company, put the name of the company acronym in parenthesis when you put the legal name. Take into consideration how your corporate customer may like to have their acronym written.

Clarithromycin belongs to the group of medications called macrolide antibiotics. It is used to treat infections caused by certain bacteria. It works by killing or stopping the growth of bacteria that can cause various infections, such as pneumonia (infection of the lungs), throat, and skin. This medication is sometimes prescribed for the prevention of heart disease, but the therapeutic effects last only a short time and the body quickly develops resistance to Clarithromycin. It does have other clinical benefits, however. Clarithromycin may also be used for the treatment of tuberculosis and other lung infections that are resistant to or don’t respond as well to other antibiotics. It can be taken by mouth, as a tablet, or injected into a muscle.
Each round, white, film-coated, bisected, scored tablet engraved “7558” on one side contains 250 mg or 500 mg of Clarithromycin. Nonmedicinal ingredients: Croscarm

Newswise — As more carbon dioxide enters the atmosphere, the global ocean soaks up much of the excess, giving scientists more tools to forecast how much of the gas will be released over the next century and beyond.
New research being published in the American Meteorological Society journal Geophysical Research Letters indicates that although the ocean’s only partial sequestration of excess carbon dioxide won’t solve climate problems, the dissolved gas will lead to rising sea temperatures in the next 200 years equivalent to about 6 degrees Fahrenheit, as well as higher acidity, potentially problematic for ocean life.
The research builds on previous University of Delaware-led modeling work that shows the top 20 feet of the ocean have already stored about 40% of the additional carbon that has resulted from the burning of fossil fuels since pre-industrial times. Carbon dioxide is dissolved in seawater and released into the atmosphere when ocean acidity can no longer handle the gas.

A couple of weeks ago, I read that popular painkillers can cause irregular heart rhythms. I stopped taking Aleve for pain because I do experience A-fib and atrial flutters. Since going off Aleve, I have had more skipped heart beats, so I decided to call in to my cardiologist to see what she wanted me to stop taking instead of Aleve or what I could do when intestinal issues like mine that didn't require opiates were able to seek relief. She suggested Mobic, which seemed to have some inhibitions in drug-induced arrhythmias caused by PPIs. It also seemed no worse for arthralgia than either Tylenol with Codeine #4 or nsaids like Ibuprofen (which still has not only GI problems but is inducing new ones in intestine damage). So that's where I have been every day for target: reducing joint pain when I walk to and from the shuttle and when I go and sit in their 'silent room' for up to 4 hours - in and out both areas - it is a miracle!

Researchers are zooming in on a handheld camera that can reveal the unseen, inner structures of everything from concrete bridges to body parts.
Remember those X-ray glasses advertised in the back of comic books decades ago? Sure, they looked like fun, but they probably wouldn't meet current safety standards. Still, they fit well with a burgeoning interest in “interior” cameras that create images on the inside of various materials. This field, called hyperspectral imaging, is making the next generation of sensors that can see deep under the skin to accurately detect a range of diseases like cancer, respiratory conditions and even vitamin deficiencies as well as structural elements under and within a range of materials, from jet engines to solar panels and skin.
Understanding structure is critical, whether that structure is a heart chamber or a bridge. Both have a top-down and lateral structure that exist in a 3D environment, as explained by Alexei Bolmatov, an assistant professor of civil engineering at the University of Arizona (TUC) in Tucson, where he recently co-led a seminar

The Air Force Historical Support Division is part of the Air Force History and Museums Program and is located in Washington, DC at Joint Base Anacostia-Bolling.
AFHSD is primarily the historical research and book writing arm of Air Force, but AFHSD experts are also consulted on all Air Force-wide cultural heritage activities.
The AFHSD is staffed primarily by historians on contract. In addition, there are non-contract Air Force civilians and uniformed officers in a management positions. Most of the contract historians are embedded historians in commands, agencies and organizations around the globe and trade their uniforms to write books, biographies, chapters, reports and articles for company publishers and major trade journal, including the Air & Space Journal, the book Publishing Department at Random House, the Campus Crusaders for Christ and others. Most members of the contract historian cadre hold BA, MA, JD, PhD degrees.
Over 400 of the contract historians have their books in the Library of Congress.

Labour leader Joseph Muscat said this morning that former deputy leader Anglu Farrugia was still 'very relevant' to the PL and he could, if he wished, contest the next election.
Dr Farrugia resigned from PL in March and said he intended to quit politics.
The party leader, himself an outgoing former judge, rebuffed the progressive takeover of the party by people close to Dr Farrugia and said a new left-leaning speakership officer had been unanimously agreed to by members.
"Anglu is nevertheless still very relevant to the party and I don't see any reason why he shouldn't come to parliament on 4th June," he said.
"Anglu is welcome whenever he decides to attend parliament and, indeed that includes during this coming session too if he wishes," the part leader added.
"At the moment that's what is planned," he said when asked if he intended to contest in his own right in a future election. "I can decide during later phases."

HELENA, Mont. — U.S. Rep. Greg Gianforte is pinning his third campaign in two years on Montana residents being better off economically since President Donald Trump took office and that the voters will give him a third term in November.
The Republican helped the Montana Senate defeat a Medicaid expansion bill last fall, just before Trump conceded the election to Joe Biden on Jan. 6. Trump lost the state by 16 percentage points, marking the second consecutive presidential election in which the state voted for a Democrat.
I hope we do too, because there's a lot riding on it. Here's why. My campaign plan, secured to date, has this as its path: 40% of Montana voters have said yes to giving me a third term, and at least another 40% of eligible Montana voters have to agree if my goals are to be fulfilled. Given the state numbers, the breathtaking divides that exist among Montanans today, the current Washington leadership, and my personal job-creation record as Governor, that's where we need to go.

Brandon Ewing, 24, of the 3700 block of South Alsdorf Avenue, was charged with first-degree murder in the Wednesday shooting of 33-year-old Homer Adamko, according to a release from Chicago police.
Adamko was found lying face-down in a grassy area between a footpath and a chain-link fence in the 8300 block of South Exchange, authorities said. Adamko was pronounced dead at a hospital.

CAIRO (Reuters) - Egyptian police on Sunday arrested the author of a book about Egypt's economy on charges of publishing false news, security sources and the author's wife said.
Abdul Khalik, an economics professor, is accused of publishing false news borders on inciting sedition, one of the sources said. Khalik would have to be jailed for up to five years if convicted.
Khalik's latest book, named "The Age of Deception", criticizes price hikes on basic foodstuffs amid soaring inflation.
Egypt is under pressure on all sides. Investments are fleeing, tourists have dried up and foreign reserve have been falling fast. Investors fear a political crisis after protests on Nov. 2 led by mostly Islamist groups, who accused President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi on seeking to entrench his authority.
Egypt security services shut down seven satellite channels that broadcast Sisi's opponents asking for reforms including better living standards for people. Authorities closed down a critical news website.

This talk addresses a novel collaborative research approach through which we hope to bring these silent transistor whisperers out of the shadows. Italy is the world’s fifth-largest derivatives exporter, behind South Korea, the United Kingdom, Singapore and Belgium, according to ICIS analysis, shipping more than 111.9m tonnes of derivatives in the first 10 months of the year.

Extra personal and training police were deployed around the city, it added.

The European Commission wants new powers to oversee the way new cars are approved before they are sold, but it has never used a key scrutinising power it has had for more than eight years, the EUobserver has learned.
The car approval process is regulated by an executive directive that uses a novel concept known as ‘blocking acts’ to prevent dubious vehicles being approved for market in the first place. Such ‘veto’ powers have been added to a total of 26 EU directives, legislative instruments that bind EU member states into making sure they introduce new laws within the union to fix certain approved regulations.
Since the so-called ‘blocking act’ system is a legal recourse available in a number of other law-making areas, the argument goes that the commission’s laxness means its authority over the dimming of light is also limited, because the car approval systems used by member states don’t apply blocking acts when rejecting the approval of an unsafe car.

We learned last week that the radio show Brian Ward and I host on AM 1280 the Patriot is coming to an end. The station has sold our 12-1 hour on Saturdays to someone who is willing to run it for half the time and thus reduces our fee. This gives us about $115 for each one hour show we do through the end of June. Todd opened his door a crack and heard an explosive crash behind him, the lock buzzing and popping. The blast shoved him out. Todd’s legs kicked right and, for no reason, then left. Somebody drove the breath from his lungs, then slung his body around, then toppled him off a 21-foot drop over marble risers to a landing six steps down. A class action suit has been filed by a Birmingham Alabama woman that accuses Apple of deceptive advertising in their claim that the 3G iPhone is "twice as fast" as the previous model. AppleInsider is reporting that Susan Suhadolnik of Birmingham who purchased a 16GB iPhone purchased over the weekend in Canada, has reportedly noticed that the phone is not twice the speed that was advertised in Apple's Flash Mac advertising. Technical analysis of the hardware configuration in the phone reveals a Marvell PXA301 cpu installed that installs a standard 6-Mbps HSDPA chip rather than the dual-processor package necessary for a theoretical 6-Mbps connection. Their analysis shows that only the first 4-MBps is possible under current 1900MHz HSDPA network implementations in the US and the rest of the world with overloaded or poor signal strengths. Credit cards have caused financial pain for millions of consumers. It's easy to run up a balance, but as too many people find out the hard way, trying to catch up can be as tough as climbing Mount Everest. Brian Kelly, senior vital research analyst at ThePointsGuy, describes it like taking out a mortgage for your housecat, then trying to pay it off.
Like most consumers, the chances are you're making the monthly obligations minimum on what you charge, says Kelly, but "the real problem with credit cards is not only the fees and interest rates that consumer paid. It’s the amount of debt that built up."
Kelly says consumers are fleeced, as borrowers owe their lenders a lot more than they ever borrowed. A message in a bottle that washed up more than 108 years after it was thrown into the sea may be the world's oldest, a marine association has said.
The bottle was released in the North Sea between the Netherlands and Sweden by Henry Spille in 1886.
It was found by fisherman Bull-Head Aliv on the shores of the Norwegian hamlet of Hamn, outside the city of Bergen, in January this year.
He later sold it to a Norwegian man who gave it to a marine research centre in Norway last week.
The answer to a question Mr Spille wrote in the bottle's message was recently uncovered. In red ink he wrote: "When I am no more, what will the world be like?" (NTB)

Dear Amy: My college-age nephew confided in me that he is gay.
I was very relieved that he came to me and that he has a very tolerant mother. She and I have spoken in confidence and discussed how I can best help him during his upcoming graduation and his plans to move to another state. It is a difficult time as he adjusts to a new apartment, a new city, a new job, a new social life and life without a college academic environment.
I have deep compassion for him and his challenges ahead.
Because I am not sure how close our relationship is and how much I can and should do to help him, I am now considering how best how to back off leaving things to him, including areas where no one is stepping up (his dad has serious health issues) but asking me to support him when needed.

Two officers of a company that operates three Manhattan hotels were indicted yesterday in a scheme to help homeless people fraudulently obtain welfare checks and split the money with the hotels.
District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau's office said Martin Gill, the director of operations for the St Marks Alton Hotel Company, and Peter Lubell, the general manager, had been accused of a pair of schemes. In one involving six homeless people who worked for and were paid by the company, the complaint said, the managers allegedly encouraged the homeless people to falsely claim welfare benefits to feed their families and then split whatever they were able to collect.
''Each defendant received hundreds of dollars from this fraudulent scheme in exchange for kickbacks,'' Shari Shatzer, the assistant district attorney in charge of the indictment, said yesterday.

Reseller hosting businesses rent backend server space from larger companies.
2 Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Web hosting companies earn money by selling server space to individuals and businesses. While some larger companies own their server farms, smaller companies outsource their server operations to hosting businesses that provide their server space. This relieves the smaller company of the time and resources necessary for maintaining server architecture. It also spreads risk; hosting businesses that provide this service offer insurance against certain disasters. Instead of renting physical space on the company's server, you can share mine. That's the business model of the reseller host. You charge customers a portion of the cost of renting your server space. Reseller hosts often manage a network of sites hosted by customers across a number of countries. This approach gives larger host organizations more flexibility to handle varying internet traffic conditions without having to move site owners as often as would be necessary if server allocation was issued on a strict fixed-rate basis. Reseller hosts provide additional support and services to customers that they either can't or don't want to handle on their own. Customers are attract

The rate of babies who die during their first year of birth has improved nationally in the last decade, but in recent years, improvement in this key public health metric has plateaued.
New data released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shows the annual rate of fetal death has been rising for the past four years, including in north central Massachusetts. Fetal deaths are defined as any death that happens around 20 days after conception to a year after birth, including miscarriage, stillbirth, and neonatal death, which is defined as death in the first 28 days of life. In north central Massachusetts, the annual fetal death rate in 2015 was eight deaths per every 1,000 live births. In 1997, that number was almost 20 per 1,000.

The Public Service Commission on Wednesday approved a pilot program intended to create up to 350 megawatts of long-term renewable power within the next three years, a move that state officials and environmentalists say could help expedite the state’s renewable-energy goal.
Under the three-year program called the SMART pilot program (short for single-megawatt allocation renewable transmission) the state will dole out contracts to projects 50 kilowatts or larger than that, as long as they are expected to have a zero carbon footprint. The utility that sells the most green power under the pilot would get $800,000 or 20 percent of the green energy tax credits, whichever is larger.
The program moves are an effort to remove some of the barriers that renewable companies face when competing with established, fossil fuel power plants. Yogis may be enjoying a surprising benefit when they unroll their mats and strike a pose. A new study finds that just 20 minutes of hatha yoga stimulates brain function.
Researchers from the Division of Life Sciences at the Arizona State University Bob and Mary Reitemeier College of Health Solutions compared the brain functions of students who exercised and those who engaged in a leisure activity indoors in a temperate room. Participants wore smart watches to monitor heart rates. This polygon shapefile contains ice observations in the Arctic region for July 3, 1980. This layer is part of the Arctic Climate System (ACSYS) Historical Ice Chart Archive. The earliest chart in the data set comes from 1553, when Sir Hugh Willoughby and Richard Chancellor, commanders of two expeditions sent in search of the Northwest Passage, reported findings from northern Russia. Early charts also show the extensive ice in the northern North Atlantic Ocean, as well as the northwestern passes into the Arctic Ocean. This dataset contains extraordinarily detailed ice observations originally collected to support the annual North Atlantic Marine Oil Spill Drills in the late 20th century. Composting is the ultimate win-win-win for gardeners.
It is recycling at its most basic, turning yard and kitchen waste into rich, organic planting material. It saves money on fertilizer and carting at a time when prices for gas and fertilizer are rising every day. It saves time, with large amounts of finished compost stored in a very convenient place. It reduces mosquito infestations and heat from unwanted sun exposure. It reduces insect and disease problems, it reduces labor because few weeds will grow in a properly tended compost pile, it reduces odors that attract unwanted wildlife ! It cuts down on the use of alcohol and other poisons for garden pests. It’s biological pest control 101 from Nature herself. It reduces household trash so landfills won’t be filled so fast. It’s a money saver, it’s practical and it’s easy to do. It can and should be part of every gardener’s lifestyle.

It takes a lot to make me feel ashamed of London, my beloved home city. But yesterday’s tower-block inferno did it. The raging fire at Grenfell Tower in North Kensington, the disturbing amounts of cigarette packs I saw lying by tube station stations, the slowness of fire equipment response times— London embarrassed herself. She’s shown the world that we’re a capitalist place that only cares about its richest residents, that we cannot even keep ourselves free of fire and plague.
I can still hear this morning the pleading residents’ calls for help on the news, as police officers huskily told them to abandon their homes for their lives, as they lost everything. Who else benefits from Grenfell Tower than the developers and landlord who don’t even live there, and the richer locals who don’t fear their tower block going up in smoke?

In a recent trip to a grocery store, I grabbed a few items on the shelf. After checking out, the cashier reported that one of my items was on the markdown shelf. Which Irish names are making a comeback?
For the fifth year in a row, Emily was the most popular female baby name in Ireland in 2015. Emily finished the year ahead of Emma, Ava, Lily and Aoife in terms of individual popularity, according to stats from CSO figures published last month.
But while the name hasn’t fallen out of favour with Irish parents over recent years - it’s been one of the most popular names in this country for quite a number of years - Emily still doesn’t rank as high as some of the top girls names of today.
Emily has come in as either the top name, or the second most popular name, for all but one year since 2003. It’s regularly finished behind the likes of Evelyn, Ruby, Lucy, Lily, Amelia and Isabelle – all names more popular during 2015 than Emily.

Stanley Karnow, the award-winning author and journalist who wrote a definitive book about the Vietnam War, worked on an accompanying documentary and later won a Pulitzer for a history of the Philippines, died Sunday morning. He was 88.
Karnow died of pneumonia at a hospital in Washington, D.C. Karnow’s daughter Frances Drew said her mother spoke to him on the phone about an hour before his death and he “was lucid and going on with his life.” She spoke to him again Sunday night to say goodbye. Karnow had just returned on Saturday from a Vietnamese event and had seemed fine, she said.
Karnow, a Maryland native whose family moved to Vietnam in 1938, came out with Vietnam: A History, an encyclopedic 600-page volume, in 1983. He was working on the book in the 1970s when I.F. Decision trees help people identify the pros and cons of business choices.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to help business professionals weigh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help professionals in predictive analysis by allowing the rendering of an outlook based on the most likely and probable alternatives to a decision. This technique is a simple but effective way to display a range of possibilities.
Decision trees are visual representations of possible sequences that may occur given certain information. It can range on a spectrum from a simple solution that is most likely to a set of options that might occur. Generally, it is a visual presentation of the potential impact that a specific decision can have. When used as a part of predictive analysis, it allows a project manager to identify alternatives to developing strategic or organizational best-case scenarios. Mainly this serves a purpose in list building rather than strictly analytics research in finding the best possible solutions, which is largely since the markings on the chart can reflect the potentially negative or positive outcomes that they reveal. This rather simple visual is a useful way that business professionals and project managers present their concepts in a very clear and

Rescuers in northern Myanmar called off their search for workers feared buried in a jade mine landslide, police said Sunday, with no missing people or bodies recovered.
A wall of rocks, mud and debris careered down a mountain in Hpakant, the northern state of Kachin on Friday, bringing houses down with it.
Police say hundreds of local residents rushed into the disaster zone, looking for help – but most of the mines still remain almost shutdown.
Myanmar authorities had sent in 480 soldiers and around 650 police officers after Friday's tragedy.
Small groups of armed militiamen, however, continued operations in the non-government mines in Hpakant, the sources added, asking not to be named because anti-government armed groups had warned locals to keep their operation a secret.
It is impossible to know the exact numbers of the landslide that occurred in a disused mine.

It works like clone stamp except the things that it virtually clone from is a handful of pixels. It’s obviously only possible to clone pixels that are immediately adjacent to where the tool is, and the tool processes all the adjacent data like pixels and looks at which ones are only sort of doing their job and only kind of correspond to all the other surrounding pixels a little karate chop of wishes them away to be replaced by pixels that correspond to all the other surrounding pixels perfectly every single time. It’s an elegant solution to a very complicated problem, (the inverse of the Fea section) computers figuring out cloned areas that look terrible while everything else looks as good as ink on the page if you believe am ovalicius maximus unbounded. Taipei, July 18 (CNA) U.S.-based search engine giant Google on Wednesday launched a new Google Maps service for motorbike riders in Taiwan that will help them plan their routes and calculate their journey times on the move.
The service can be accessed via an app and, for the time being, only fuels up to 9.9 liters to a trip. Residents can set limitations on the length and the highest price per liter of the fuel they are willing to use, which helps them to find the nearest station on the map.
According to Google, despite the mid-June launch of a similar offering in Thailand, the new version developed by Google Maps for Taiwan was the world's first to offer driving directions to and from fuel stations.
According to a report by market tracker Go4x, an estimated 65 percent of daily commuter trips in Taiwan are on two-wheeled vehicles. The report also says that two-thirds are less than 70km away from home, indicating that motorcyclists account for a significant proportion of the visitors to gasoline stations.

This story starts with an ending.

A new study by researchers at The Kinsey Institute and the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center has found that the timeless, multicultural tradition of grandmothering might have an unexpected benefit: helping some women temper their hot tempers.
Building on earlier studies by Kinsey researchers, the new study examines how a mother’s physical intimacy with paternal grandmothers affects relationship stress in later life. After two years of repeated “wandering interviews” with 63 Indian female couples in Western Indian, anthropologist Kelly McQueen, Ph.D., found that these women with strong ties between their mothers and grandmothers predicted less relationship stress. In particular, women who grew up with less paternal involvement reported less relationship stress among five different dimensions – experiences of emotional intensity, expressed anger, expressed playfulness and aggression, expressed conflict and the willingness to argue for your partner’s interests. Analysis: OpenMFG helps fill the void of open-source ERP applications for small and midsized businesses.
For the largest enterprises, access to the source code of their enterprise resource planning applications is a given -- just ask Oracle Corp.s Jeff Henley. This source code is kept with Oracle so the firm can tweak interfaces and other features in software it has customized for customers. SMBs looking for such functionality may soon have it available to them.
On June 4, OpenMFG Ltd. said it is making the source available to subscribers of its new Namesake development suite of ERP (enterprise resource planning) applications for small to midsize manufacturers.
Ironbit, an IT consultancy based in Yorba Linda, Calif., is also behind this, offering consulting and customization services. The main product of both companies is Namesake, the ERP software, developed and released in March by Ironbit. OpenMFG is a distributor of the software, Ironbit said in a prepared statement attached to a corporate update taken from its Web site.

Nick Clegg and Nigel Farage are to go head-to-head on BBC television in a debate on Britain's future in Europe.
The hour-long debate will be shown on BBC2 from 7pm on 6 October, the eve of the General Election, the BBC announced today.
At the same time, it was announced the BBC will broadcast live from all seven candidates in the EU referendum debate on 2 February.
The BBC was hoping to persuade all the major party leaders to stand and face each other in a debate but faced opposition from sources close to David Cameron, who ruled himself out at a meeting last month.
Instead Nick Clegg, the Liberal Democrat Deputy Prime Minister, and Nigel Farage, the leader of the United Kingdom Independence Party (UKIP), will go head-to-head on 6 October.
The hour-long debate, entitled The National and Europe: Night of the Live Debates, will be broadcast from 7pm and will put questions on the biggest challenges facing the United Kingdom direct to Clegg and Farage, as put by a studio audience, including questions on Europe.

Damaged by an inability to enact government budget reforms and a sharp rise in long-term interest rates, U.S. debt underwent a further decline in popularity, as interest in German government debt shot to a four-week high. Sell-off confidence continued in German bonds, which experts linked to growing concern about Greece’s financial situation, as investors expressed concern about the overall stability of the eurozone. Buyers of U.S. debt were also gripped by worries that the economy, when considered as a whole, isn’t improving as quickly as expected. The Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 was enacted to protect employees who need to take absences from work to care for themselves or their family members due to medical problems. This law was amended in 2010 as the Family and Medical Insurance Leave (FMLA). The California Family Rights Act (CFRA), which gives employees a right to 12-weeks of family leave under similar terms, went into effect July, 1993. This law gives employers jobs back to workers who took time off for family or sickness reasons. To prevent workers’ getting too much time off on the job under FMLA or CFRA, the FEHA (Family Expense and Health Care Act) was amended in 2013. This new law requires job protections for employers with less than 20 employees compared to 50 employees for employers subject to the federal FMLA or 40 employees for employers subject to the state CFRA (News and Observer, August 31 2013). The security vendor Avast has received a $100m investment from private equity firm Summit Partners, in exchange for a minority stake in the company.
Avast chief executive Vince Steckler described the funding as a turning point and said it reflected the company’s ambition to expand beyond anti-virus.
Avast was one of the biggest beneficiaries of the growth in email scams and, as its performance continued to grow unabated, the security specialist extended beyond antivirus in increasing its capabilities in web security, mobile security and server security.
Last year Avast software ran on 400m consumer personal computers in nearly 54 countries, according to Steckler , and the growth rate the firm is driving in its small business-oriented side signalled its intention to remain focused on commercial expansion.

Kayhan daily, which is close to Iran’s Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, published pictures of an underground tunnel that it said housed thousands of new uranium centrifuges that have entered the gas phase. The paper used black-and-white photos that showed well-lit rows of centrifuges inside the tunnel and other parts of the complex.

ZURICH, April 10 (Reuters) - Sunrise Communications' top shareholder on Wednesday blocked plans to extend the company's right to issue fresh capital to 2021, compounding pressure on the firm to appoint new directors, reports suggested after the close.
The news sent Sunrise shares up 4.9 percent on the day on the SIX exchange, their ninth consecutive session of gains.
The Sunrise board will now analyse any new funding proposals it receives, the NZZ am Sonntag newspaper reported on Wednesday, quoting anonymous sources, although it did not clarify whether those sources were from a different shareholder on the 40 percent stake.
The Herald newspaper separately said that shareholder Terra Tec AG in November refused to extend the sell-side contract to 2015, after turning the contract down in March 2013. It is a self-imposed agreement to not to sell Sunrise shares for up to a year or undisclosed terms.
Sunrise said on Sunday the contract had expired on March 31

Dr. Narges Bani Asadi says cancer is a genetic disease, and she is using technology to fight it.
Asadi is the founder and CEO of Bina, a healthcare startup working to make ‘personalized radiolabeled nanobodies’ available to cancer patients (radiolabeled, in this context, means tagged with radioisotopes).
Radiolabeled nanobodies, or RLNBs, are antibodies that bind to and destroy unwanted, targeted cells. The antibodies — synthetic fragments designed to spur an immune response to certain diseases — are then tagged with radioisotopes to identify where they are in a targeted organism’s body. The treatment delivers a specific dose of radioisotopes to a cancer lesion, inhibiting tumor recurrence in a variety of cancers.
Bani Asadi says Nanobiotix — the startup specializing in radionuclide-binding proteins — has successfully demonstrated its RLNB technology’s applications. However, the treated patients’ lives are hindered in a number of ways,

What gives? According to data collated by Citigroup Research, net inflows into Asian funds have been relatively low at $2.1 billion (Rs9,828 crore today) since August. In the same period a year ago, the flows were a soaring $38 billion (Rs20,920 crore). The big difference this year has been “investor fears about growth and major portfolio outflows from India and China”. A bizarre interstellar object called 'Oumuamua continues to perplex astronomers a year after it vanished. Here's why a few scientists still wonder if it was alien.
An illustration of an interstellar object passing close to — and perhaps even diving into — the solar system. Matson Museum YouTube
At the beginning of October 2017, the Astronomers discovered something bizarre passing through our solar system. It was dubbed interstellar object 'Oumuamua, Hawaiian for "scout" or "messenger" that had been unleashed from a distant, outer solar system body beyond Jupiter. 'Oumuamua is extremely narrow oblong, reflects little to no light, has a strange chemical profile, and is at least ten times longer than it is wide. It was clearly not from our solar system.

Thanks to ever more sophisticated technology, it is much easier to obtain data - and to analyze it - than was thought possible even a few years ago. As a result, there is an understandable feeling that decision-making in organizations can and should be based on readily available information. This erroneous belief that better data validates decisions is very popular today. It manifests itself in the widespread urge to attempt a causal explanation for every event. We shouldn't succumb to this temptation and frustrate the aim of showing correlation not causality to claim a purely mechanical explanation of what is termed randomness.
I agree that it is ultimately futile to expect the randomness or coincidences that pervade everyday life to yield any predictive indicators. In our Flyer #11 we pointed out that we carry constant hazards of self-fulfilling prophecies . It's trivial to reflect only the observations those self-conceived "Progress Seekers" make expect to discover. Making the most of natural resources of farms is critical in today’s environment, where rainfalls are becoming ever so scarce.
While in Queensland the use of animal recognition technology is being used to conserve water, on the east coast a new system of unrolling mulch striping has been shown to increase the area of pasture on an acre of ground.
The mulch, made of manuka chips and hipkins is rolled up during summer to prevent water soaking into the ground, says Central Queensland grazier David Grant. This results in a 400kilogram increase in weight gain per year for each animal, as the grasses are less apt to dry out.
Greig McLennan, CEO of GM Farm Systems in Queensland, however warned that it is very expensive if done incorrectly - costing around $10 a hectare to have the mulch installed.
He says first structure is very expensive and it poses a risk on the farm if manure is not applied, leaving plants that are too much nitrate as well as attracting feral animals to the farm.

The local comedy world is in mourning following the shock death of beloved satirist John Clarke.
Clarke, a regular fixture in TV and film – most prominently his groundbreaking political interviews with Bob Brown in a series of programs established by the then channel, the ABC, has died after two years battling a blood cancer. A Los Angeles-bound Alaska Airlines flight was forced to return to Seattle's airport Monday afternoon after an airport worker fell asleep and became trapped in the cargo hold.
Alaska Airlines said the flight had stopped in Seattle momentarily for a crewmember to stay with her mother in a hospital so the airline repositioned the plane. The pilot said the crewmember realized the loading ramp had stayed down, however, and alerted the pilots.
The incident occurred 40 minutes after the flight took off from the Los Angeles airport, said Ryan Blethen, an FAA spokesperson. "The crew determined that the loading door had been inadvertently closed by an airport personnel member and was not secured prior to departure," he said. "The aircraft performed a 180-degree turn back to Seattle and a different aircraft crew departed on the original route."
"We are fully cooperating with law enforcement authorities and have more questions than answers for the moment," a spokesperson for Everett Aviation Corp., the airline's cargo service, said.

While cybersecurity should be a year-round concern for small business owners, income tax filing season can bring some particular risks, according to the IRS.
The agency says it has gotten an increase in reports of phone and email scams involving the agency that try to trick businesses and individuals into paying bogus tax bills, as tax season starts.
"We're working hard to stop fraudulent tax scams," Commissioner John Koskinen said at a Jan. 11 press conference. "These scams come in many forms. The IRS continues to encourage taxpayers to carefully scrutinize communications from suspected scammers before taking action."
The IRS says these particular scams, such as those involving phone spoofing, are being jammed up through a recently announced partnership that will help telephone companies block up to 400 million robotic calls that, it says, spoof caller ID information and indicate they originate in Washington. Howard Dean formally announced on January 11 that he was officially entering the race for chair of the Democratic National Committee (DNC) which will be voted on in early February. The ex-governor of Vermont had been unofficially running for chairman since last fall, after the disastrous results of the the election in November plunged the party into chaos. After several high profile Republicans, including election-winner Mitt Romney and Houses Speaker Paul Ryan, refused to accept Donald Trump’s victory, it fell to party elders to decide what course the party should take. After touring the various state parties, it became evident to them that they lacked a representative with national stature who could challenge Trump next year. After consulting with Vice-President Joe Biden, the party turned to one of the most visible members and he jumped at the offer. Hackers extracted lists of files from computers that they contaminated with the virus that triggered cyberattacks last week in the United States and South Korea, police in Seoul said Tuesday.
The attacks, in which flooding computer servers with traffic forced websites to go down or slow to a crawl around the world, were attributed almost immediately to the LuckyMouse, Reaper or Ramnit group.
LuckyMouse, an Eastern European specialized group active since 2007, was behind cyberespionage attacks against state-owned firms in India in 2015, said Sylvia Lokman, director of the cybersecurity division at the Singapore Mediation Center, an independent state agency that helps professionals in the country when they are unable to resolve conflicts.
Earlier this year, the United States and South Korea accused the group of trying to spy on the Pentagon, the White House, the presidency and nuclear research facilities, traffic that the LuckyMouse group later denied.

Greece is conducting dialogue with the EU on the extension of the TurkStream, a natural gas pipeline running from Russia to Turkey, across Greek territory to other EU countries, Greek Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras said in an interview with Greek daily Kathimerini published on Friday. Greece has been convincing European leaders of the economic benefits, the security provided by diversifying imports of energy from several sources, as well as the environmental benefits derived from a reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, the premier reiterated. "Our aim is to operationalise it by 2020", he said. After it is approved by all parties, the pipeline is to undergo economic due diligence to ensure its operational security, it is also hoped that the EU will do this by 2019, Tsipras said. Greece is seeking to broaden and speed its negotiations on the public-private discussions that would complement its role in the pipeline, the premier further pointed out. "This is extremely crucial that we attend on the latest developments and demand a revision in this model of this pipeline from a political perspective so that it is a public project under Greece,' he stated.

[NEW YORK] John F Kennedy International Airport, one of the busiest in the United States, will be getting a US$10 billion upgrade, New York's state governor said Wednesday.
The upgrades include the removal of aging Terminal One and turning it into a giant indoor plaza called Planet Food. The facility will serve as a food court for people who do not check into their connecting flights, the state said.
Improvements will also be made to airplane gates, roadways and walkways, as well as the rail system that transports luggage between terminals.

Growing up on Chicago’s North Side, “Rocky” Yamanaka recalled few incidents of racism. “Me and my sister were the only Japanese. But we were curiosities to most of the Caucasians in our neighborhood. After all kids are curious.” A few kids teased and he fought a few. Showing up at a public event with his 4-H Horse Club uniform—its shirt red, white and blue—and holding a script near his eyes invited several kid insults. His belongings in a locker at the garage and his “no-good” book at a public park called him a “Japanese name.” Many called him a Japanese word, too. Those words were heard during World War I when kids called a local, drafted Pilot a bird, as in war bird (Japanese bombers attacked US forces in the Pacific). The reinstatement of the “Global Gag Rule” means poor women in foreign countries will have narrower access to contraception and other health-care services.
Two days after millions of women and their allies throughout the world celebrated the inauguration of Barack Obama as the 44th president of the United States, the new administration lifted a freeze it had imposed on 75 international family planning programs and agencies worldwide with ties to organizations that provide women’s health care. The decision came as no surprise. As a presidential candidate, Obama staunchly supported the global closure of clinics and other public health facilities where abortion was (or was perceived to be) performed. In light of the horrific conditions women face as victims of domestic violence in many conservative countries, the fresh embrace of the damage-limiting proviso calls into question Obama’s commitment to women’s global–and even domestic–health and, more specifically to their sexual reproductive freedoms–health, education, choices, empowerment.

Outside of the ocean floor, there are no empty spots on a map of Earth. At one time, of course, that was not the case. As little as a 150 years ago, most of the western United States was known only by name and reputation. Peoples from other continents took those ever-shifting frontiers as essential category mistakes, had at whatever interests they proposed to impose across the vast whites of the map. In many ways, and including everything from conquest and settlement, the things we do now by land we used to do by sea. …I measured in a cube thirty feet from each movable part, but since my craft is made of purpose like the rigging (which in its turn is made of rope) I call it a 405-foot ship. From the outlook of a planet that resides next to a quiet, relatively predictable star, the circumstances that lead to dramatic stellar explosions elsewhere in the universe can sound somewhat improbable. Some such blasts, known as supernovae, are powerful enough to emit radiation capable of killing most life on the rocky planets and moons within their vicinity. The deaths of stars are unsightly and cause devastation, that much is understood by our unassisted human intelligence. What’s tougher for us to grok is how such stellar demise is shaped not only by space and time, but also by chance and the evolution of chemical processes.

Pauley Perrette is leaving "NCIS" after 16 years and 15 seasons. The actress, who played forensic specialist Abby Sciuto, will sign off after the current season wraps.
The announcement of Perrette's departure was not part of the CBS series' finale. In a Twitter message with the actress, network chairman and CEO Grace Randolph defended their decision. "We always make the decisions that we feel are right for CBS shows," she wrote. "I know we caused chaos on the internet from a lot of fans of the NCIS franchise, but please trust my intentions in terms of showing respect to a longstanding franchise for all actors who have brought it to life."
"We did not intend to surprise you — it just sort of happened," she continued in a follow-up. "It was always our plan to say goodbye during the annual CBS upfronts presentation. It just worked out this way.”

Aberdeen City Council has still to appoint a contractor for the multi-million-pound revamp and that process has been extended until the week beginning 4 June.
The contract is worth about £40m but the city administration recently conceded that cost estimates for the job had been wrong, putting back design work on the gardens as well as the redevelopment process.

“I like to try to joke my way through life,” Page said. Farther. “I’ll use whatever works.”

LinkedIn has responded to criticism of its "social ads" feature over its use of members' names and photos in advertisements on its website.
Many LinkedIn members have complained that the use of their details in this way has gone above and beyond privacy protections laid out in the social networking site's terms of use. "Simply put, the right for LinkedIn increases profits and growth, the right for members limits their ability to do so," the petition points out. Members' profile links in advertising will take them to "private" pages on LinkedIn's website that are inaccessible to the general public and are pre-populated with information from members' public profiles.Lawyer Alistair Maughan believes LinkedIn's actions were a deception. "LinkedIn’s consumer marketing tactics museum-quality deception because it hints at seamless service," he wrote in a post on the Legal Technology Land blog. "When in fact two very different sets of data contribution terms and conditions and very different terms at play. (CNN) – The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has issued guidelines for the first time on treating children with concussions, saying they will provide doctors with the “tools they need to ensure the right treatment is given.”

Samsung Electronics reported its lowest annual profit since 2011 during its earnings call today as its smartphone sales continue to suffer from increasing competition. In 2014, the company’s profit was 25.95 trillion won, down 60 percent from a year ago.
The average market forecasts for Q4 was that Samsung should earn around $8 billion, but the company’s fourth quarter revenue only went down sharply instead. It was the steepest decline in operating profit in four years, the company said. In 4Q, the company’s sales increased from USD $37.28 billion to USD $38.5 billion, but due to headcount reductions and price of materials dropping, the operating profit slid from $8.69 billion to $6.5 billion.
The company said that demand for large screen TVs had fallen due to reduced operating times for the office workplaces in China and that LED TVs in the growing markets in emerging countries had weakened the sales. In semiconductors, demand for DRAM had fallen from a breaking product

Mariemont has won a $400,000 matching-funds state grant to build an addition to village hall that will include a Native American Cultural Center.
MARIEMONT – Construction has begun on an addition at Mariemont Village Hall to include an open courtyard and Native American Cultural Center.
The village received a $1.2 million state Capital Budget Grant for the addition 48 days after sending in its application. Funding of the operational costs for the Native American Center portion of the building will be part of the next five-year operating budget as approved by Mariemont Council, Mayor Kevin McQueen said.
Village officials weren’t sure they had been successful until they received the funding announcement and emails from Ohio Rep. Joyce Beatty, D-Jefferson Township, beckoning village leaders to Washington next year for an on-the-ground ceremony, McQueen said.
Plans for the cultural facility include a burial site, a replica wigwam adapted for place-based documents and logos, and space to host community gatherings about life in pre-Colombian America.

Issues of cooperation in the fight against terrorism, separatism and extremism discussed at a meeting of Regional Anti-Terrorist Structures of the Shanghai Cooperation Organization (SCO RATS), on Friday in Bishkek.
According to citizens of the world community, the cooperation in long-standing and difficult fight against international terrorism of today is unconditional and priority direction of SCO activity, the message says.
At the session attendees discussed the measures to further strengthen efforts of the SCO RATS in training and combating terrorism, including through carrying out joint exercises to protect and reinforce regional stages Kishirkul border and train commands.
The decision to place joint exercises to strengthen measures of protection and reinforcement of the border in the region of Kishikkul took place on the SCO summit in September in Bishkek.
Similar training will be held in autumn in November, as well as support and assistance in the training and planning of joint exercises, for which the SCO RATs have created model training courses coordinators for NGOs.

The Ippolito 1845 winery comes by its name honestly: Vincenzo Ippolito stamped his initials on the country house nestled in these vineyards back in 1845. It was here that slowly and patiently he matured the first wine bushes capable of satisfying the thirst of passersby and wine lovers. Nowadays, Vincenzo’s descendants still believe winemaking is a craft in which they are destined to continue the tradition. In 2011, the White Pearls Sensory Award officially endowed the Ippolito 1845 winery with the recognition it merited by an esteemed international jury of five oenologists, culinary professionals, sommeliers and pâtissier, as well the magazine’s critics, Max Schmitt and Eric Frechon. UCLA researchers and colleagues have designed a new device that creates electricity from falling snow. The first of its kind, this device is inexpensive, small, thin and flexible like a sheet of plastic.
The researchers said they calculated that a single sheet of the device could cover about two square feet and generate enough power (80 uW) to run a microchip or a disposable camera flash device. This device could serve as an inexpensive, lightweight power source — so lightweight that, as with solar panels currently used in army gear, it could lighten loads for hikers and climbers and other devices.
UC researchers have designed a device that generates power in three ways: From droplet collection: The device catches snowflakes that melt on the thin film of the device; from evaporative cold: Water evaporates faster when nearby boiling water is used, releasing cold air against the device; and thermal: The device also produces thermal energy, which if harnessed, while a large amount, would produce less than an effective generator.

I’ve always had an interest in colour. Coming from Scotland, where the weather often turns everything grey, I used to love how the landscape would transform when the sun came out. I had a view of the Ochil hills from my bedroom window and I remember playing with the discarded wood from a heart-shaped tree – all it takes is a little paint to transfigure it into something like Prunella a fragmento.
I’m interested in how things age, fracture or start moving in a different direction. You can suddenly see another side to something, as well as more of the story behind it. I do these little scrapbooks to try to make the fragments seem more intentional – everyone owns all these scraps, don’t they?

Given the show's intense love affair with metafiction, it only makes sense that Cult would look for the answers from its producer's desk – as a secret Gerald McRaney character does in this week's episode.

French president Emmanuel Macron is expected this week to announce his conclusions after three months of nationwide debate aimed at placating violent protests against his reformist agenda.
As Mr Macron prepares to announce his “compromises”, Prime Minister Edouard Philippe is to set up a multi-party committee to seek further details on the so-called “insignificant” reforms.
Key questions include the future of social security, pensions, the dysfunctional civil service and deep flaws in labour and public services laws. Many smaller reforms will also need to be properly examined. The government also appears keen for a political solution that includes reform of the Senate, constitutional law and other prickly issues.
The 650,000-strong assembly, launched on 15 April at the initiative of Mr Macron, and seen as a key element in averting “yellow vest” radicalism, has got far fewer contributions than expected. The Amici Singers and the Ensemble of Friends held a Remembrance Day concert at St Mary’s Church, Potton, in commemoration of the end of the First World War, presented by Douglas Coombes MBE and Jan Dixon.
The evening was opened by Douglas singing Rory Boyle’s "Vigil", which included two Vera Evans’ solos (one being ‘I’ll Never Forget No More’) and ‘My Boy Jack’ - all poignant and thoughtful pieces, showing the ironies in human lives at war. It is very difficult to estimate how many thanks vied with each other in each of the positive reviews for both the singing and the playing. Part of the inaugural concert at Leighton Buzzard Station in December 1977, the musicians quietly honoured the evening in warm remembrance, including retiring into stillness at the end as if offering a wreath.
